data.title: Blues at Rangers tonight (7 p.m.) ... pre-game notes
data.text:
Pre-game notes courtesy of the Rangers:

NEW YORK RANGERS vs. ST. LOUIS BLUES

Thursday, Nov. 12, 2015, 7:00 p.m. ET

Madison Square Garden – New York, NY

Rangers: 11-2-2 (24 pts)

Blues: 11-3-1 (23 pts)

TONIGHT’S GAME

The Rangers play their 16th game of the 2015-16 season against the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden (7:00 p.m. ET - TV: MSG Network; Radio: WOR 710 AM). New York enters the contest with a 10-game point streak (8-0-2) and a six-game winning streak. In addition, the Rangers have won eight of their last nine games (8-0-1). The Blueshirts enter the contest with an 11-2-2 record, following a 3-0 win against the Carolina Hurricanes on Nov. 10 at MSG.

FAST START

The following are notes regarding the Rangers' start to the 2015-16 season:

The Rangers' 11 wins and 24 points thus far are tied for the most recorded through the first 15 games of a season in franchise history.

Rangers goaltenders Henrik Lundqvist and Antti Raanta have combined to post a league-best 1.46 GAA (22 goals allowed in 905:57 of ice time) and a league-best .954 SV% (457 saves on 479 shots) this season. The Rangers' .954 SV% is the highest the team has posted through 15 games of a season since the NHL began tracking the statistic in 1975-76.

Lundqvist has posted a .949 SV% in his first 12 appearances this season. Lundqvist's save percentage is the highest any Rangers goaltender has posted in his first 12 appearances of a season since the NHL began tracking the statistic.

The Rangers have allowed 24 goals thus far this season (Note: not including team goals awarded for a shootout win). According to the Elias Sports Bureau, the Rangers have allowed 24 goals or fewer in the first 15 games of a season for the first time since 1939-40 and for the sixth time in franchise history (1926-27, 1928-29, 1933-34, 1937-38, 1939-40, and 2015-16).

The Blueshirts are the first team that has recorded at least 24 points in the first 15 games of a season in the season after winning the Presidents' Trophy since Detroit in 2005-06 (Red Wings won the Presidents' Trophy in 2003-04 and 2005-06).

RANGERS VS. BLUES

All-Time: 76-42-16-1 (45-13-6-1 at home; 31-29-10-0 on the road)

2015-16: Tonight’s game is the first of two meetings between the Rangers and Blues, and the only meeting between the two teams at MSG. The Rangers and Blues will play against each other Feb. 25 (at St. Louis).

2014-15: The Rangers posted a 1-0-1 record (0-0-1 at home; 1-0-0 on the road) against St. Louis. New York registered three goals in each of the two games and outscored the Blues, 2-0, in the first period of those contests. Rick Nash tied for first among all skaters in goals (two), assists (two), and points (four) in the season series, while Chris Kreider registered three points (two goals, one assist). Henrik Lundqvist posted a 1-0-0 record, along with a 2.00 GAA and a .920 SV% in one appearance.

Dating back to Nov. 3, 2002, 13 of 15 meetings between the Rangers and Blues have been decided by two or fewer goals. In addition, 11 of those contests have been decided by one goal or fewer.

RANGERS-BLUES CONNECTIONS

Glen Sather played part of one season with St. Louis (1973-74).

Alain Vigneault played parts of two seasons with the Blues (1981-82 - 1982-83).

Rangers TV Analyst Joe Micheletti played parts of three seasons with St. Louis (1979-80 - 1981-82).

Scott Gomez played two seasons with the Rangers (2007-08 - 2008-09).

Henrik Lundqvist and Alexander Steen were teammates with Frolunda in Sweden for five seasons (1999-00 - 2003-04). During the five-year stretch, Lundqvist and Steen were teammates with Frolunda in the Swedish Elite League (now Swedish Hockey League), as well as with Frolunda's junior team and U-18 team.

Dylan McIlrath and Joel Edmundson were teammates with the Moose Jaw Warriors of the Western Hockey League (WHL) for two seasons (2010-11 - 2011-12).

Kevin Shattenkirk is a native of New Rochelle, NY.

Blues Senior Advisor of Amateur Scouting Larry Pleau was the Rangers Assistant GM for eight seasons (1989-90 - 1996-97) and Director of Player Personnel for five seasons (1992-93 - 1996-97). During his tenure with the Rangers, Pleau helped the team win the Stanley Cup in 1993-94.

INDIVIDUAL CAREER STATISTICS VS. BLUES

Henrik Lundqvist - 6 GP, 1-4-0, 2.67 GAA, .907 SV% - Lundqvist has allowed two or fewer goals in three of five career starts and four of six career appearances against St. Louis, including each of his last two contests against the Blues.

Rick Nash - 52 GP, 23-21-44 - Nash enters the contest with a four-game point streak against St. Louis (three goals, four assists) and he has tallied 17 points (six goals, 11 assists) in his last 17 games against the Blues.

Derick Brassard - 24 GP, 3-16-19 - Brassard has tallied more assists and points against St. Louis than against any other NHL opponent in his career. He has notched five points (one goal, four assists) in his last six games against the Blues, including four assists in his last four games against St. Louis.

POINT TAKEN

The Rangers rank second in the NHL in points percentage (.800) this season. The Blueshirts lead the NHL in points percentage (.706) since the start of last season.

In addition:

The Rangers have posted a .750 points percentage since Jan. 1, 2015 (44-13-5 record over the span).

Since Dec. 8, 2014, the Rangers have posted a 53-14-5 record in 72 games (111 points; .771 points percentage).

New York has posted the best record in the NHL since Jan. 1, 2014 (89-36-13 in 138 games; .692 points percentage).

MAKING THE DIFFERENCE

New York enters the contest ranked second in the NHL in goal differential in 2015-16 (plus-21; 45-24 - Note: doesn't include team goals awarded for shootout wins). The Rangers also lead the NHL in goal differential during 5-on-5 play (plus-23). The Blueshirts lead the NHL in both goals for (36) and goals against (13) at 5-on-5 in 2015-16.

SHUTTING THE DOOR

The Blueshirts have allowed two goals or fewer in nine of their last 10 games (12 goals allowed over the span; 11 goals allowed in regulation and the five-minute overtime period), including each of the last six games, and in 12 of 15 games this season. In addition, the Rangers have allowed two goals or fewer in regulation in each of the last 10 games. The Blueshirts have allowed one goal or fewer in seven of the last nine contests, including five of the last six games, and have allowed one goal or fewer in regulation in eight of the last 10 games. The Rangers lead the NHL in goals against per game (1.60) in 2015-16. In addition, the Blueshirts have allowed two or fewer goals in all 11 of their wins this season and have posted an 11-0-1 record in games which they have allowed two goals or fewer. Dating back to Mar. 2, 2015, the Rangers have allowed two goals or fewer in 28 of 36 games.

HOME COOKING

The Blueshirts enter the contest with a six-game winning streak at home and have outscored their opponent, 23-5, over the span. In addition, the Rangers have earned at least one point in each of their last seven home games (6-0-1) and in eight of nine home games in 2015-16 (7-1-1). Dating back to last season, the Blueshirts have earned at least one point in 38 of their last 48 home contests (32-10-6), including 21 of their last 26 home games (18-5-3).

FIRST IN SCORE

The Rangers have tallied the first goal of the game in 10 of 15 contests in 2015-16. The Rangers have posted an 8-1-1 record when registering the first goal of the game this season. New York has posted a 49-7-4 record when tallying the first goal of the game since the start of last season. The Rangers lead the NHL in first period goals (17) and rank second in the league in goal differential during the first period (plus-10; 17-7) this season. MAKING NOISE ON THE WESTERN FRONT

Since the start of the 2014-15 season, the Rangers have posted a 24-6-5 record in 35 games against Western Conference opponents. This season, the Blueshirts have posted a 6-1-0 record against Western Conference opponents. New York has outscored Western Conference teams, 22-10, thus far in 2015-16.

NOVEMBER REIGN

The Rangers have posted a 4-0-0 record in four games in November this season. Since the 2005-06 season, the Blueshirts have posted a 77-42-9 record in November. New York leads the NHL in wins in November since 2005-06.

KING HENRIK

Henrik Lundqvist became the Rangers' all-time leader in overall appearances (regular season + playoffs combined) by a goaltender and overall saves (regular season + playoffs combined) on Nov. 10 vs. Carolina. Lundqvist also became the all-time leader in combined regular season and playoff appearances by an NHL goaltender who only played with one team in his career.

Lundqvist is tied for second in the NHL in wins (eight), ranks third in SV% (.949), and ranks fourth in GAA (1.65) in 2015-16. This season, Lundqvist has posted his best GAA and SV% through his first 12 appearances of a season in his career, and his eight wins are tied for the most he has earned through his first 12 appearances of a season.

Lundqvist has been named one of the game’s Three Stars in 10 of the 12 contests he has played in 2015-16, including 10 of his last 11 appearances and each of his last eight appearances. He has been named the game’s First Star six times and the game’s Third Star four times. In addition, he has been named the game’s First Star in six of the eight games he has won this season. He has allowed two goals or fewer in 11 of 12 appearances this season, including each of his last eight appearances, and he has made at least 30 saves in seven of his 12 appearances. In games which he has made at least 30 saves, Lundqvist has posted a 6-0-1 record, along with a 1.56 GAA, a .957 SV%, and 1 SO.

OSCAR-WORTHY PERFORMANCE

Oscar Lindberg is tied for second in the NHL in even strength goals (seven) and is tied for eighth in plus/minus rating (plus-nine) in 2015-16. In addition, Lindberg leads NHL rookies in even strength goals, is tied for first in goals (seven), is tied for second in even strength points (10) and plus/minus rating, and ranks fourth in points (11) this season. Lindberg is the only NHL player who has recorded at least seven even strength goals, 10 even strength points, and a plus-nine rating in 2015-16. In addition, he is the only Ranger who has posted a plus/minus rating of even or better in each of the team’s first 15 games this season.

RICK ROLLING

Rick Nash has registered two multi-point games in his last three contests, tallying five points (one goal, four assists) and posting a plus-five rating over the span. He has also notched seven points (two goals, five assists) and has posted a plus-six rating in his last seven games.

HEY HEY HAYES

Kevin Hayes has posted three separate three-game point streaks over the first 15 games of the 2015-16 season. He has tallied a point in nine contests in 2015-16, and the Blueshirts have posted an 8-0-1 record in games which he has notched a point. Hayes has registered a point in six of the last eight games, recording seven points (three goals, four assists) over the span. He has also recorded four points (two goals, two assists) in the last four games. Hayes has notched 24 points (nine goals, 15 assists) and has posted a plus-13 rating in 33 career games against Western Conference opponents, including nine points (three goals, six assists) in 15 games against teams in the Central Division.

WELCOME MATS

Mats Zuccarello has registered 12 points (seven goals, five assists) in the last 14 games, including nine points (four goals, five assists) in the last nine games and six points (three goals, three assists) in the last five contests. He leads the Rangers in points (12) and is tied for the team lead in goals (seven) this season, and all 12 of his points have either been a goal or the primary assist on a goal.

DAN’S THE MAN

Dan Girardi enters tonight’s contest tied with Dean Prentice for 14th place on the Rangers’ all-time games played list (666). The Rangers alternate captain has notched an assist/point in each of the last two games (two assists). Girardi has also recorded an assist/point in three of the last four games (three assists) and has posted a plus-one rating or better in each of the four contests (plus-five rating over the span). He has notched a point in four of the last six games, registering four points (one goal, three assists) in those contests.

AV SQUAD

Alain Vigneault ranks 17th on the NHL's all-time wins list for coaches (531). Vigneault, who enters the contest with 179 games coached with the Rangers, will tie Fred Shero for 12th place on the franchise's all-time games coached list. Vigneault's team has posted a 240-111-40 record in 391 games since the start of the 2010-11 season.

SPECIAL TEAMS

Power Play:

The Rangers were 0-for-2 (4:00) on Nov. 10 vs. Carolina.

New York has tallied a power play goal in two of the last three games (2-for-8; 25.0%) and in five of the last nine games (5-for-21; 23.8%).

Penalty Kill:

The Rangers were 6-for-6 (11:57) on Nov. 10 vs. Carolina.

New York ranks fifth in the NHL on the penalty kill in 2015-16 (88%; 44-for-50).

The Blueshirts have not allowed a power play goal in nine of the last 11 games (32-for-34; 94.1%).

UPCOMING MILESTONES

Dominic Moore - 1 game away from 700 in his NHL career

Derick Brassard - 2 games away from 500 in his NHL career; 5 points away from 300 in his NHL career

INJURIES (4 Man-Games Lost to Injury)

None

RECENT TRANSACTIONS

None

THIS DAY IN RANGERS HISTORY

Nov. 11, 1973 – Rod Gilbert registered his 273rd career goal as a Ranger, passing Andy Bathgate to become the franchise’s all-time leader in goals. Gilbert recorded two goals as the Blueshirts defeated the Islanders, 5-2. Gilbert is still the Rangers’ all-time leader in goals with 406.

Nov. 12, 1991 – The Rangers acquired Jeff Beukeboom from the Edmonton Oilers in exchange for David Shaw. The Beukeboom-Shaw trade completed the future considerations part of the trade that sent Mark Messier to the Rangers on Oct. 4, 1991.

Nov. 12, 2007 – Mark Messier was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame.

Photos by Getty Images.
